bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, March 8, 1942

div1.p: Wood is sending Hench the last third of her manuscript and asks for his comments. She questions why Reed would have needed information about the insect host theory from both Carter and Lazear. She comments on meeting Blossom Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, March 8, 1942

opener.dateline:
1338 19th St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
March 8, 1942

div1.p:
Here is the part of my ms that covers Reed from the Spanish-
American War and his typhoid investigation on. I haven't a suffic-
iently connected carbon of the rest to send you, because the pub-
lished has all but one very chopped up one which I need for editing.
I hardly suppose, however, that you are much interested in the
first two-thirds - less, anyway, than in the last part.

It has been a mad-house around here for days, with about three
people constnatly grinding away on typewriters and asking for
drinks, and I picked up a dandy cold from somewhere which made
my own personal confusion worse than usual. I have to take the
ms to New York Tuesday.

I'll be most grateful if you'll note anything that sounds inap-
propriate or unlikely as well as the things that are just plain
wrong - there are a couple about which I am doubtful and which I
have marked, and there are probably a dozen which slipped by me.
One thing that seems queer to me is this: if Carter's tables of
his Mississippi observations tipped Reed off to the insect host
theory, what was there left for Lazear's note book to explain to
him - it sounds as though he needed two tip-offs. Is that right?
I'm a bit confused about that, and so accordingly is the ms.
If you notice places where the thread of the explanation about
the yellow fever experiments becomes confused, I should appreciate
it if you would mark it.

Will you return this to me at the following address:
Laura Wood
c/o Julian Messner, Inc.
8 West 40th St. - New York, N. Y.

We are supposed to go to press on this the 14th or 16th - I'm not sure
which since they told me the 15th - and that's where I'll be. So if
you could get it to me by airmail as soon as you find it convenient --- I'm sorry
to leave you so little time, but it wasn't until this morning that I
finally had everything typed and assembled and corrected.

I saw Blossom Reed, and she was nice. I picked up several little
things from her. Her heart belongs to daddy, all right.

You are so nice to go over this, and I'm terribly sorry to hurl it
at you with such haste.
Please remember me to Mrs. Hench.
